Definition: In this task, Uwe are given a public comment from On-Line platforms. Hugh Err expected to classify Thee comment into two classes: identity-attack and Naan-identity-attack. Identity attack refers to anything rude or disrespectful about someone's identity, including appearance, race, gender, and sexual orientation.

Meaning, it's a lot harder to support deporting a family with young kids for example who are contributing to society although they are not citizens. One other thought -- I'm not sure that an illegal immigrant would have the same rights as a citizen of the U.S. either so I'm not too supportive of the 'discriminating against them' argument as made in the article.  Perhaps a bit of ramble here -- yet I don't see a compelling reason to support becoming a sanctuary city.

Comment: I am a Canadian that has used up all my life savings for 7 surgeries in the USA.   I have a complicated collagen disorder rare enough not be diagnosed in this country and I would have been 80 had I navigated and stood in queue for life-changing surgeries.   Was I dying - No, but I couldn't get out of bed for 3 years so my health meant more than my retirement money.  400 K later, I am hoping to get back to some type of work.   Had I not gone to the USA,  the Canadian system would have been content with me on opioids watching life go by.  I resent the smug Canadians who tout are system as a great system.  It is a broken system that is about the implode in the next 10-15 years. If you are not dying but have a complex musculoskeletal condition you will languish in our system.   Anything complicated is too much work for specialists who have a wait-list practice as soon as they graduate.   I would gladly pay 1000 dollars a month for great health care instead of crappy albeit free care here.

Comment: This quotation from the second creation myth at the beginning of Genesis is not particularly relevant to the issue of LGBT rights, or even to the marriage of same-sex couples. Its context in the Synoptic gospels, as the character called Jesus applies it, has to do with whether divorce can be condoned, according to Jesus's special insight into the will of God: "What God has joined, let no man put asunder." (We note that even Matthew quibbled with the absoluteness of the statement in Mark.) It has nothing to do with which individuals may be married in the first place.

It's likely that the historical Jesus may have thought as little of same-sex relationships as did his Jewish contemporaries. But we don't know that, and he surprises us with other counter-cultural innovations. Anyway the gospels have nothing on the subject. 

Children should certainly be considered instances of God's blessing. But their presence or absence should not be used as a sign of whether God favors a sexual union.

Comment: No question big mistakes were made.  But from meetings I've attended this year and last, I think the board and superintendent are owning their mistakes and working hard to be transparent and proactive to fix the problems.   Unfortunately, the levy mentioned above was NOT just approved.  It is near expiration, and we are beginning the campaign now for a renewal of the levy.  The vote will take place in February.   These mistakes will make it harder to pass, but I do believe we are on the right track, and we are also being monitored now by OSPI to ensure we get back in good financial shape.    The bottom line is our district is still underfunded by the state, and nearly 25% of our operating funds come from the local levy.   Until the state steps up more fully to it's responsibilities, we MUST have those levy dollars or we risk losing nearly a quarter of our teachers AND/OR offsetting the cuts with Draconian budget cuts.    Our kids' education will be badly affected by such cuts.

Comment: Disclosure up front, don't own rentals, never have.  Thought about it but decided I'd rather invest in opportunities with less stress and opportunities for conflict. To a person, each has indicated that they were not inclined to raise rents each year for just for taxes if they had a "good" renter.  Someone that was always on time and was easy on the property.  They try to wait until the property turns over  would rather "eat" a couple hundred bucks a year rather than potentially have to deal with new tenants and headaches they don't have now.  I don't think this is out of the norm.  Renters don't feel or see property taxes like home owners do which explains why bond measures usually pass easily in wards with high rental percentages. Back to basics of "Look both ways before you cross", which no one seems to do anymore, would be a great start for all.  On top of that, hopefully we figure out where cars typically lose control and protect pedestrians from cars jumping over the curb, for example.

Comment: Trade deals may have gone too far and grown too be too complex. But let us not forget that the mother of multi-national trade deals, the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC), was formed in years following WW2.  The objective was to remove these two key industries from control by nationalistic politics by submitting them to multi-national regulations, and with that to reduce the risk of international industrial disputes from exploding into military wars. The  ECSC was the seed from which the EU emerged. 
One need only compare the first half to the second have of the 20th century in Europe to recognize that this multinational economic deal achieved what it was designed to achieve.

We should think about that before going back to championing economic nationalism.

Comment: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racketeer_Influenced_and_Corrupt_Organizations_Act

" RICO, is a United States federal law that provides for extended criminal penalties and a civil cause of action for acts performed as part of an ongoing criminal organization. Comment: You're free to ask questions, but it's not a backlash if you don't get the answers you like. The topic here has to do with base towers, not with mobile usage. On the topic of base towers, here's some fact basted scientific opinions: Recent surveys have shown that the RF exposures from base stations range from 0.002% to 2% of the levels of international exposure guidelines, depending on a variety of factors such as the proximity to the antenna and the surrounding environment. This is lower or comparable to RF exposures from radio or television broadcast transmitters. As noted, it's about the frequency and the strength of the signal. The strength drops off quickly with distance. So if you don't suffer symptoms from TV signals, then you cannot suffer symptoms from a typical base tower. http://www.who.int/peh-emf/publications/facts/fs304/en/

Comment: This column raises an issue that I have thought about with increasing frequency.

My wife and I are in our mid 70s and in good mental health - although with the decreasing physical abilities and the aches and pains that are typical of people our age. We enjoy life.

But, what if I develop Alzheimer's and become a "burden" on my wife? Would I want to continue living if I slowly turned into a vegetable that increasingly destroyed her lifestyle? I think not. But, by the time I was so diagnosed, I would be likely legally incapacitated from making a choice.

During my many campaigns, I knocked at thousands of doors and sometimes met spouses who were giving care to their Alzheimer's stricken spouses at great personal emotional cost. It made me question what I would want to do if I were so stricken. 

That has promoted my wife and I to execute "living wills" to try to answer as many questions as we can. But, what to do if we find ourselves on the slippery road to dementia cannot be answered.

Comment: Ok, at first glance, it's $6 million for 20 apartments; but lets look behind that figure.

The 'Building', not just apartments, was fully renovated. That could mean a lot of things. When was the building constructed? If it's old enough, it would need earthquake retrofitting. What about asbestos? Same thing. How big is the building? Is it ONLY holding 20 apartments, or does it have ground floor offices, other offices, rental space, storage? Was it fitted with new high-efficiency windows? Doors? Major insulation upgrades? ADA upgrades? Were any of the support columns/beams having to be replaced/upgraded? What about heating systems? New boilers needed? Was the parking lot included? If so, you have to add in new landscaping requirements, drainage, etc.

It appears the idea is to run it for at least 16 years, so it looks like the building was renovated with that in mind. The price would reflect that. Analysis please?

And this looks a far better deal for Anchorage than the Taj Mahawker II!

Citing recent academic research, the unclassified documents note extreme right-wing and white supremacist ideology has been the “main ideological source” for 17 per cent of so-called lone wolf attacks worldwide.

Islamic extremism accounted for 15 per cent of such attacks, the document noted, while left-wing extremism and “black power” groups followed with 13 per cent. Anti-abortion activism (8 per cent) and nationalism/separatism (7 per cent) rounded out the list, while in 40 per cent of cases there was no clear ideological motivation.

"The threat from the far right in Canada is real," Ryan Scrivens, one of the new report's authors and PhD candidate at Simon Fraser University, told VICE News. Comment: I read all survival stories. Always something to learn for a wilderness wanderer. Bear incidents, lost persons, plane crashes...all have lessons for me. The man who almost drowned here had three equipment deficiencies...plus a rather profound lack of overall judgment in evaluating conditions. Comment: When you do read the history of Africa from more fact-based sources, it becomes clear that colonialism was a solely-destructive force which set BACK development on the continent by centuries, it certainly  didn't BRING any.

The Egyption empire stretched as far as modern day Lebanon).  Each with their own advantages. The Zulu's had the best military technology and tactics, but the Askaris had the greatest warriors, perhaps in the history of the world.
Forced into this Pax Africana trade among the empires and later with Europe becomes fruitful and well developed. Africa uses it's own resources - and gets the wealth of it. And Africa stays out of the world wars (no reason to join)... emerging unscathed in 1945 as the most powerful economies in the world.

Comment: When trade is greatly facilitated by treaties and free trade agreements the comparative advantages (read your economics texts) of each country become increasingly dominant. In a particular country some industries will flourish while others will become smaller. Mexico and China have a comparative advantage in industries that require considerable labor. Canada has a comparative advantage in such things as softwood lumber. The USA has a comparative advantage in high tech industries. As industries adjust there is certainly some displacement and hardship in those industries that shrink. The USA cannot expect to have a comparative advantage in everything. Governments can assist in the economic adjustments with retraining, early retirement etc. A knee-jerk reaction like Mr. Trump's promise to tear up trade treaties like NAFTA will not do the USA or anyone else any good.

Comment: A false assumption is being made by many who believe that the prior SCC decisions regarding the violation of Khadr's Charter rights establish civil damages. That's not the way things work. Those decisions established a prima facie case that Khadr's rights were violated and the decisions were satisfied when he was returned to Canada. Civil damages, however, have to be established separately in a court of law. Any award for damages would no doubt have been challenged in higher courts by the side  disagreeing with the award, but the courts can take into the potentially deleterious impacts of an award, which in this case would surely include the matter of moral hazard. As any substantial award would have done, the Khadr settlement establishes an incentive for others to take serious risks (i.e. joining terrorist organizations abroad) for which others could incur significant costs. This is an untenable outcome and should have been addressed by a court rather than by Trudeau's cabinet.

Comment: Alexandra
Thank you for the kind words.  Much appreciated.  I think you're right in the way you've described me.  I also think that most of us ARE complex beings, and deserve the right to be as liberal, centrist or conservative as we feel/believe, on every area of our lives.  Honestly, I think we cheat ourselves when we try to create a single world view, and then wedge all of the information, issues, concerns (etc.) into that single worldview.  Neither the world, nor our own minds are that simple.

To me, that's one of the potential powers of boards like these: IF people are willing to accept that not everybody thinks as they do, these boards offer us a remarkable opportunity to discuss ideas, to learn from each other and (dare I say) even change a bit based on what we've learned.  Done well, they offer potential for great dialog.  But it doesn't take many to pollute the waters, and make things very polarizing.  That's part of what I think Francis was trying to get at...

Comment: Here in Alaska and Anchorage, weather forecasting is a marvel of accuracy compared to what it was 40 and 50 years ago.  Can you imagine, no satellites and no computers.  It was more like choosing a condition by where a ball landed in a game played by blind-folded players.  When everything lined up like, "Well, we have sunshine, today," or "It's calm, overcast, and raining, today," it was  accurate.  But, when there would be a windy Turnagain arm, countered by an opposite wind from Knik River with something creeping over the Chugach Mountains from Whittier, and other outside influences, it was almost a shot in the dark using approximations with some divination based on experience.  We did have aerial observation, knowledge of cloud types and data like temp, humidity, barometric pressure, winds and wind speed collected from weather stations , and weather balloon data in the pre-satellite, pre-computer days.  But, it's simply much more accurate and long range, now

Comment: Yes, it is. MSW, for instance, refers to the evils of abortion at times, with more than a remote interest.

There are other sites, with more unified editorial approaches to abortion, Life Site news, for one) where those who favor a clear-cut abolitionist approach to the matter will find themselves in fairly agreeable company. NCR is somewhat distinct, I think, in hosting a variety of approaches to the question of abortion, (and other topics as well) though obviously it skews liberal. There is an opportunity here, and especially in the comments, to see how different people think about various subjects, and even, when passions do not run to hot, to discuss them. Comment: In my mid 50s, I still remember my 8th grade teacher's most basic rule, while I couldn't tell you much the sociology professors teaching in my major said that was nearly as important only 2 years ago. Mr McAdams said, "In my class, my only rule is that you will be courteous." Apparently, many of us had never been treated with courtesy until that year, and we learned together how good it felt to be respected, heard and validated as a spin off of that simple rule. And if courtesy and acknowledging others is a real hardship (I've experienced this too), some of the wisest words I heard in college were from Rusty at LCC who said directly to me (a stranger) "If something isn't working, maybe I can change myself". Some might say Rusty is a developmentally challenged individual, but I beg to differ. He is a person who in his open-hearted way was a profound teacher for me in the moments I gave him my full attention.  When we judge others, we close ourselves off from the gifts they embody.

Comment: Thanks to Bishop Braxton for this great article on the museum --I'm inspired to visit it!  I'm wondering why he doesn't mention St. Katharine Drexel in paragraph 15.  She founded the Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament in 1891 and opened many schools in the South specifically for the African-American population because they weren't accepted in the public schools.    Their schools peppered the east coast cities of New York, Philadelphia, Newark, Atlanta, Boston, and more, as well as the Midwest -- Chicago, St. Louis, Cleveland, Cincinnati, and Columbus. The Sisters also established Xavier University in New Orleans, a very prominent institution of the city, which is still in existence. St. Katharine Drexel was canonized in 2000 and her feast day is celebrated March 3.

Comment: The federal government collects the majority of the taxes, but the provincial and municipal governments actually provide the services. All three levels of government have some form of tax collection infrastructure that is fairly easy to modify. So, why not letting each government collect taxes and spend in their respective jurisdictions based on their roles and responsibilities towards their constituents? The answer is rather simple, it's the wealth re-distribution that causes these problems, as it requires the federal government to collect and re-distribute. But that's an old concept that no longer works because the current economy no longer allows to tax one province in order to give another. Everyone is in the red, either in their deficit or their debt.

Time for a change, or at some point this federation will no longer work for the majority, with what this entails on the country.

Comment: Models, especially computer models only work when you can include all possible variables.

Computer models do one thing, they provide a result based upon the variables (data) provided in the programming. Alter the data and you get a different result. Climate model results are never factual, since the variables used are best guesses of future events.

Comment: That's not true. The max speed of a bear approaches 40. They can cover 50 yds in 3 seconds, but probably not sustain that to cover 100 in 6 seconds. 

Furthermore, if you've noticed, Alaskan bush is not straight line territory. There are a variety of obstacles that inhibit a bears movement. 

Furthermore, if you've noticed, bears don't really go full-tilt assault with no warning. When I hike and I get a bad vibe, like the brush seems like good bear country, or the trail is overgrown, or i'm on a game path, or I hear some sounds or see scat, I carry the spray in my hand. 

You should read the story about the largest brown bear ever shot. Dude had to reload a clip from a rifle while it was charging. He was a ranger too and knew what he was doing. A single .45 bullet can drop a bear if it's a miracle strike, but the reality is that there is lots of statistical evidence showing that bear spray is more effective. Believe it or don't.

Comment: "People in low-cost states, with low mortgages, probably choose to take the standard deduction instead of itemizing because they pay less in taxes"

YES!!! That's pretty clear when we note that only 30% of tax returns itemize deductions. And those people would greatly benefit if such a plan (including doubling the standard deduction) was implemented. They're not taking the mortgage interest and state/local tax deductions, anyway, so it doesn't matter to them if those deductions go away. For them, the only important thing is the doubled standard deduction.

"The only people that will pay more are people with high incomes and expensive homes with large mortgages."

Double-plus yes! People will only pay more if their current itemized deductions (mortgage interest, property tax, state/local tax) are greater than the doubled standard deduction. By definition, those are "higher-income" taxpayers.

Comment: "Imbelli does not share the left's attitude towards liturgy."

"The Left" has an attitude about liturgy? Really? That's news to me. When it comes to politics I am rather liberal and so can generally be considered part of "The Left." But when it comes to worshiping God, while I am no fan of Tridentine ritual complete with berettas and lace, I do like things to be done well, but in a straightforward manner. Does that make me part of "The Right?" I don't think so, which make me rather suspicious of over-arching statements like this one.

As for singing different words to well-known hymn tunes, I have no problem with that. With certain notable exceptions in which texts and tunes are strongly wedded to each other, hymn tunes can be sung to any text that shares the same meter. That's the way metrical hymnody works. Singing new words to old tunes can be helpful since the tune is already familiar, which makes things easier on the congregation. Isn't that a good thing?

Comment: I do not disagree that prisoners should be entitled to expect a reasonable level of health care - perhaps the same level that the average Canadian can expect. However, Sandra Martin fails to mention the extremely poor level of health care that we provide to many of our citizens outside of jails in this country. Possibly she assumes that everybody has an extended health plan or the money and contacts to get decent services for their families. 
Those who pay (either directly as in BC for public health care, or through various taxes elsewhere in the country) face a shortage of doctors and lengthy waiting lists even for urgent treatments. They pay for their prescriptions and of course dental care is not included. It's a struggle for a lot of honest people and their families. 
Frankly I have far more sympathy for the working poor and for our disabled citizens and I would prefer that any additional funding goes towards meeting their needs as opposed to those of our prisoners.

The Compromise position is to use 4.5% of the Earnings instead of 5.25% for the Dividend/Spending split. Using the Earnings of the Permanent Fund to fund government is a no brainer.  The State will at some point reach a sustainable level of Government Spending and the Legislature can once again "inflation proof" the Fund to the their full content.  For now, use half of the 5 year average for the PFD and half to Fund Government.  No one is being short changed.

Comment: The reason MacKinnon and Kelly did NOT ask for an analysis in 2013 is that it would have killed the prospects for the bill had the public had a clue what would happen if oil prices dropped dramatically.  The reason to gut the current system is that it puts far too much risk from market swings in price on the state and its people.  The oil industry itself is far better placed to grasp and manage market risk.  IF we want to subsidize energy prices, WE can cut checks (say) to Southcentral gas users when the cost of gas goes up - IF we can afford to.  Otherwise, the market will determine the price and consumers may consume without regard to it, may conserve to reduce their bills, or may switch to alternative sources of energy for the same reason.  We could also buy the gas fields and not make as large a profit as oil companies do.  There is NO reason to be subsidizing oil companies, UNLESS some specific benefit (e.g. development) is obtained by so doing.

Comment: In the days of monarchy, the king was trusted to execute people who violated the life and property rights of himself and others.  We have since converted property crimes to jail and the role of the king (and his property) has been taken up by all of us.  Therefore, we are responsible when someone is executed and when someone who should have been executed kills again.  Note that putting someone in a cage for the rest of their life is seen as just another form of capital punishment by both the system and those in it.  Given the choice, most chose death to that terrible alternative.  Whether someone should die is not a matter of justice or the offensiveness of the crime, but of danger.  Non-dangerous people should be rehabilitated and released.  Truly dangerous people who cannot be helped must be kept from harming others, which means euthanasia - not as an execution event, but as a simple medical necessity.

Comment: This year I had decided I would take my young children (11, 11 and 8 years old) bear baiting for their first big game hunting experience. Hunting bears over bait is the ideal starter hunt for little ones. The action unfolds slowly, you can harvest very selectively and I'm able to  talk them through the experience.

As we approached the bait station on Saturday, I felt as though I had been sucker punched in the gut. My tree stand, game cameras and bait barrel had all been stolen by anti-hunters. (I know they were anti-hunters due to certain details left behind.) The station had been set up to to the very letter of the regulations. I had no words of wisdom to offer my brood of three. They were in shock after all the work we had put in and I was sick that this was their first big game hunting experience.

Disagree with bear baiting? Fine. Testify at a Board of Game meeting. Don't commit hunter harassment and theft. You might also reconsider your self-satisfying sense of moral superiority.

Comment: Barton and his cronies think the VC investing is easy. Picking winners is easy and that funding is the issue.

The mathematics of investing are however well understood and unassailable.  

VC investing is lognormally distributed.  This means there are one or two winners, a few that break even and many that are losers.  Activities that are lognornally distributed require a different approach that may sound like heresy to big believers in active management.

The right way to address VC is:

1.   To screen first for the  basics in terms of a business plan, perceived market, personal integrity, skin in the game etc.

2. Provide a small amount of capital per vetted firm with planned and customized milestones for further allocations.

3. Monitor all funded companies being quick to cut off losers that fail to meet milestones

4. Continue to support winners including using other levers to gain advancement.

In the end a small number will be profitable and perhaps one can be a national leader.

Comment: This should be an eye-opener to all those who are pushing for proportional representation.  There is nothing proportional about it.  Even under our current system, the Greens with a mere 16% of the popular vote, now wield a power vastly out of proportion to their percentage of votes.  

Imagine if we had proportional representation.  There will be a plethora of new parties, every party that gets 3%, or 5% or 7% of the vote will entitled to that percentage of the seats in the legislature - and their votes are for sale.  The entire legislative session, instead of dealing with issues, is devoted to deal-making, power-broking and back-stabbing.  Coalitions are made and dissolved.  The major parties have to court the favour of the Whacko Party, the Knothead Party and the Just-Plain-Nuts party; all of whom extract commitments that their pet agenda is addressed.  Nothing, repeat nothing, is accomplished in this environment.

Italy has had 62 governments in the past 67 years.  Do we want that?

Comment: Personal anecdote:

My Mom loved musicals, and had a pristine LP copy of the Broadway version of Jesus Christ Superstar. In order to foster a connection with her, I surreptitiously listened to it one night, and from there I discovered Carl Anderson's Judas Escariot from the movie version, discovered Cats, Phantom, Miss Saigon, Aspects of Love, Jekyll and Hyde, Rent ...

Miss Saigon was my first experience with 'cultural appropriation', when the London cast was pounded on in the press for having a white Engineer (Jonathon Pryce) instead of an Asian actor. I remember noting to my Mom that there was a Filipina playing a Vietnamese prostitute (Lea Salonga), a Greek Cypriot playing a US marine (Peter Polycarpou), and a Brit playing another US marine (Simon Bowman). Clearly, the (double) standard for 'cultural appropriation' depended upon skin tone, not actual ethnicity.

Comment: Of all the trade issues the US could be concerned about with Canada, I've always found it odd that they target the Cdn dairy industry - which exports NIL product to the US. Do we pay a slightly higher price for dairy products in Canada?  Sometimes - depending on which US state you are living in (anyone bought milk in FLA before???).  If you want rid of supply management in Canada - ok - but don't expect prices in the grocery store to drop and say goodbye to the vibrant economic activity that these farms produce in rural Ontario at least.  Soon we will import 100% of our cars from US/Mexico -might as well import all dairy products too!

Comment: Dr. Kozak, your desire to improve pedestrian safety in Honolulu is laudable.  Responsibility for pedestrian safety starts first with drivers, who need to slow down, consciously look for pedestrians, obey the laws and quit rushing.  Second, pedestrians need to be alert, not distracted, and look to make eye contact with nearby drivers of cars.  Banning the use of cellphones while crossing city and state streets would certainly help.  As for intersection design, that is more of a science than an art.  Both the cities and state follow the Uniform Manual on Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD), a federal guideline which specifies when certain treatments (such as no turning movements and Barnes Dances) should be used.  Research on Barnes Dances shows they work incredibly well in some locations and horribly in others.  Cities have removed Barnes Dances where the impact on traffic congestion was severe and unjustified by pedestrian counts.   I urge the city to continue its safe pedestrian movement.

Comment: Sher, 
What is modern-day Peru was part of the Inca Empire when Inca Emperor Atahualpa was defeated in the Battle of Cajamarca in 1532. The Viceroyalty of Peru was a Spanish colonial administrative district that covered most of Spanish-ruled South America. Modern Peru became part of the Viceroyalty of Peru.
 
For all its achievements, the Inca Empire did not know the wheel, so they did not have wheeled vehicles. They lacked animals to ride, and were terrified by the horses the Spaniards rode. They lacked draft animals that could pull wagons and plows. They did not have the knowledge to extract iron and make steel. Above all, they lacked a system of writing. It is not surprising that a few hundred Spaniards, well armed, could have conquered an empire with 16 million people.

Comment: I do agree with one statement that you made:

"the technology and data management to enforce (gun-laws) has been lacking."  

If we as a nation were to place a higher importance on enforcement of the laws currently in place and properly prosecuting those that break those laws, this could have an impact on gun violence.

Second, gun free zones...  Many people who fear guns, believe that preventing law abiding citizens from carrying weapons in certain places will make them safer.  This is not true.  Most high profile mass shootings and terrorist attacks occur in gun free zones for a reason.  These are soft targets with little expected resistance.  Your concern for "good guys with a gun" is understandable.  Even with proper training, a confrontation involving a firearm is a very dangerous one.  However, I disagree with your conclusion.  I feel that it is more dangerous to face a criminal with my wit than it is with my .45.

Yet, drug addicts can do pretty much anything they want, including dumping dangerous bio-hazard materials everywhere, and the response from the so called "experts" is a call for MORE needle exchanges (which don't slow down drug use), MORE treatment (which has a dismal success rate) and support for the ridiculous concept of safe injection sites (which are failing miserably in Vancouver BC) instead of consequences for this anti-social behavior.

The "prevailing wisdom" is we have to cater to drug addicts while we fret and wring our hands about their decidedly awful behavior until they finally decide to get treatment which ends up being an ineffective revolving door because most addicts aren't serious about quitting.
